section.title: Introduction
section.para: The Michigan Section maintains a very strong NTS system. The Michigan Net was the first spot frequency net in the nation, perhaps in the world, and developed many of the procedures used throughout NTS. In spite of the constant drumbeat of "NTS is dying", Michigan's nets continue to pass more traffic year after year, and are continually improving their integration into the State of Michigan's emergency response strategy.

Each of Michigan's affiliated and unaffiliated nets has its strengths and weaknesses. In an effort to continually improve Michigan's NTS system, this document seeks to outline some of the better practices developed by some nets in order that others may improve their own operation.

section.title: Differences between nets
section.para: The various nets are each unique. Some of this uniqueness is valuable, some is not. The greater consistency we can achieve among the Michigan nets, the more efficient they will be and the easier it will be for new members to join a net. The point of this document is to identify good practices in the hope that the nets will adopt them where appropriate.

On the other hand, there are differences between the nets that serve a purpose. Some nets are hard-core traffic nets. QMN is the prime example, with the Michigan Traffic Net not far behind. At the other extreme are nets that focus on fraternity, such as the Wolverine Net. These nets pass little or no traffic. Some nets have a training component which may be important to many of the net's members. Each net serves a particular niche.

section.title: Net Members
section.para: One important distinction between the nets is that they serve different constituencies. Many net members feel that handling traffic is boring and takes time away from the important business of the net. Others find the idle chit-chat to be a waste of time, and want to get the traffic passed as efficiently as possible.

One thing is consistent among these members, however; when traffic is passed, it should be passed as expiditiously as possible. Hard-core traffic handlers pride themselves on efficiency. Those less interested in traffic handling want to get it out of the way as quickly as possible.
